org.jgrapes.core

Interface Manager

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<AttachedComponent>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Component, ComponentProxy, ComponentVertex, File, HandlingErrorPrinter, HttpServer, NioDispatcher, Server

    public interface Manager
extends java.lang.Iterable<AttachedComponent>
    Provides methods for manipulating the component hierarchy and for firing events. Every component has access to a manager implementation that manages the component.

    The Manager for a component that extends from Component is provided by the base class itself. Components that only implement the AttachedComponent interface get an associated Manager assigned to their annotated attribute.

    Author:
    Michael N. Lipp
    See Also:
    AttachedComponent

    • Method Detail

      • detach

        AttachedComponent detach()
        Detaches the component managed by this manager (with its children, if any) from the component tree that it currently belongs to.

        This method results in a IllegalStateException if called on a tree before a Start event has been fired on it. The Reason for this restriction is that distributing buffered events between the two separated trees cannot easily be defined in an intuitive way.

        Returns:
        the component (for comfortable chaining)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if invoked before a Start event

      • attach

        <T extends AttachedComponent> T attach(T child)
        Attaches the given component node (or complete tree) as a child to the component managed by this manager. The node or tree may not have been started.
        Parameters:
        child - the component to add
        Returns:
        the added component (for comfortable chaining)

      • getChildren

        java.util.List<AttachedComponent> getChildren()
        Returns the child components of the component managed by this manager as unmodifiable list.
        Returns:
        the child components

      • getParent

        AttachedComponent getParent()
        Returns the parent of the component managed by this manager.
        Returns:
        the parent component or null if the component is not registered with another component

      • getRoot

        AttachedComponent getRoot()
        Returns the root of the tree the component managed by this manager belongs to.
        Returns:
        the root

      • getChannel

        Channel getChannel()
        Returns the channel of the component managed by this manager.
        Returns:
        the channel that the component's handlers listen on by default and that fire(Event, Channel...) sends the event to

      • fire

        <T> Event<T> fire(Event<T> event,
                  Channel... channels)
        Fires the given event on the given channel. If no channels are specified as parameters, the event is fired on the event's channel (see EventBase.getChannels()). If the event doesn't specify channels either, the event is fired on the channel of the component managed by this manager (see getChannel()).

        If an event is fired inside an event handler, it is added to the EventPipeline that has invoked the handler. If an event is fired by some other thread (not associated with a pipeline), a new pipeline is created for handling the event (and any events triggered by it).

        Parameters:
        event - the event to fire
        channels - the channels to fire the event on
        Returns:
        the event (for easy chaining)

      • addHandler

        void addHandler(java.lang.String method,
                java.lang.Object eventKey,
                java.lang.Object channelKey,
                int priority)
        Adds a method of the component managed by this manager as a handler for a specific event and channel. The method with the given name must be annotated as DynamicHandler and must have a single argument of type Event (or a derived type as appropriate for the event type to be handled).
        Parameters:
        method - the name of the method that implements the handler
        eventKey - the event key that should be used for matching this handler with an event. This is equivalent to an events/namedEvents parameter used with a single value in the handler annotation, but here all kinds of Objects are allowed as key values.
        channelKey - the channel key that should be used for matching this handler with a channel. This is equivalent to a channels/namedChannels parameter used with a single value in the handler annotation, but here all kinds of Objects are allowed as key values. If the actual object provided is a Channel, its match key is used for matching.
        priority - the priority of the handler

      • addHandler

        void addHandler(java.lang.String method,
                java.lang.Object channelKey)
        add a handler like addHandler(String, Object, Object, int) but take the values for event and priority from the annotation.

      • activeEventPipeline

        EventPipeline activeEventPipeline()
        Returns the pipeline used when firing an event.
        Returns:
        the event pipeline
        See Also:
        fire(Event, Channel...)

      • newEventPipeline

        EventPipeline newEventPipeline()
        Return a new EventPipeline that processes the added events using a thread from a thread pool.
        Returns:
        the pipeline

      • newSyncEventPipeline

        EventPipeline newSyncEventPipeline()
        Return a new EventPipeline that processes an added event (and all events caused by it) before returning from the EventPipeline.fire(T, org.jgrapes.core.Channel...) method.

        The returned event pipeline is not thread-safe, i.e. no other thread may call add while an invocation of add is being processed.

        Returns:
        the pipeline

      • registerAsGenerator

        void registerAsGenerator()
        Register the managed component as a running generator.

      • unregisterAsGenerator

        void unregisterAsGenerator()
        Unregister the managed component as a running generator.
